review.title: Avoiding and Escaping Depressions in Real-Time Heuristic Search
review.abstract: Heuristics used for solving hard real-time search problems have regions with depressions. Such regions are bounded areas of the search space in which the heuristic function is inaccurate compared to the actual cost to reach a solution. Early real-time search algorithms, like LRTA*, easily become trapped in those regions since the heuristic values of their states may need to be updated multiple times, which results in costly solutions. State-of-the-art real-time search algorithms, like LSS-LRTA* or LRTA*(k), improve LRTA*s mechanism to update the heuristic, resulting in improved performance. Those algorithms, however, do not guide search towards avoiding depressed regions. This paper presents depression avoidance, a simple real-time search principle to guide search towards avoiding states that have been marked as part of a heuristic depression. We propose two ways in which depression avoidance can be implemented: mark-and-avoid and move-to-border. We implement these strategies on top of LSS-LRTA* and RTAA*, producing 4 new real-time heuristic search algorithms: aLSS-LRTA*, daLSS-LRTA*, aRTAA*, and daRTAA*. When the objective is to find a single solution by running the real-time search algorithm once, we show that daLSS-LRTA* and daRTAA* outperform their predecessors sometimes by one order of magnitude. Of the four new algorithms, daRTAA* produces the best solutions given a fixed deadline on the average time allowed per planning episode. We prove all our algorithms have good theoretical properties: in finite search spaces, they find a solution if one exists, and converge to an optimal after a number of trials.

sections.heading: 2.1 Real-Time Search
sections.text: The objective of a search algorithm is to make an agent's journey from the initial state to a destination state that moves between movements, an amount of the calculation limited by a constant. An example situation is finding the path in a previously unknown grid-like environment, where the agent has enough memory to store his current belief in the structure of the search space. Furthermore, the search in open space (Zelinsky, 1992; Koenig, Tovey, & Smirnov, 2003) is initially assumed to be barrier-free. The agent is able to detect a limited form of sensor technology: only obstacles in neighboring states can be detected. If obstacles are detected, the agent updates its map accordingly. Many state-of-the-art heuristic search algorithms can be described by the pseudo-code in Algorithm 1. The algorithm iteratively executes a lookahead update cycle until the target is reached.

sections.heading: 3. LSS-LRTA∗ and RTAA∗
sections.text: Now we are describing LSS-LRTA * and RTAA *, the two most advanced heuristic real-time search algorithms most relevant to this paper. We are making two small contributions to understanding these two algorithms. First, we are conducting an experimental comparison of these algorithms using benchmarks that were not previously considered. Second, we are demonstrating two theoretical results aimed at understanding the differences between their updating mechanisms (Propositions 1 and 2). To our knowledge, none of these results appear in the literature.

sections.heading: 4. Heuristic Depressions
sections.text: The definition of depression is central to our algorithm. Intuitively, a heuristic depression is a limited region of the search space that contains states whose heuristic value is actually caught in relation to the heuristic values of states bordering on depression. Depression, of course, exists in heuristics, which is used along with real-time heuristic search algorithms. As we have seen above, heuristic algorithms can gradually build solutions by updating the heuristic values associated with certain states as more information is collected from the environment. Ishida (1992) gave a constructive definition of heuristic depression. The construction begins with a node s so that its heuristic value is equal to or lower than that of the thesurinfinite states. The region is then expanded by adding a state to its boundary when all states in the resulting region have a heuristic value that is lower or equal.

sections.heading: 5. Depression Avoidance
sections.text: A major problem in solving the already discussed LSS-LRTA and RTAA problems is the presence of heuristic depression. State-of-the-art algorithms are able to essentially solve this problem through extensive learning and / or comprehensive advance planning. By engaging in more forward planning, the chances are low that a state outside of depression will eventually be selected to enter a depression. On the other hand, by learning the heuristic values of several states at the same time, fewer movements may be required to increase the heuristic values of states inside a depression that is high enough to make it disappear. As such, LSS-LRTA procedures performed with a high value for the predictive parameters that trigger the depression faster than LRTA parameters may be executed to increase the depth of search equal to 1 for two reasons: (1) because the heuristic function for states in D is faster and (2) because we sometimes come up with a high predictive value for depression.

We will continue with results that require other evidence; in particular, the termination and convergence to an optimal solution. sections.heading: 8. Discussion
sections.text: There are a number of aspects of our work that merit discussion, and we focus on two of them: first, we discuss the environment in which we evaluated our work, focusing on identifying performance improvements in the first study for a search in an a priori unknown area, without considering other settings; second, we discuss in which scenarios our algorithms may not show average performance improvements that were shown in the previous section.

sections.text: In the first approach, states that are demonstrably in a depression are marked in the update phase and then, if possible, avoided when deciding on the next step. In the second approach, the algorithm selects the state that appears to be closer to the edge of a depression as the next step. Both approaches can be implemented efficiently. Mark-and-avoid requires very little effort, resulting in an almost negligible increase in the time per planning phase. metadata.abstractText: Heuristics used for solving hard real-time search problems have regions with depressions. Such regions are bounded areas of the search space in which the heuristic function is inaccurate compared to the actual cost to reach a solution. Early real-time search algorithms, like LRTA∗, easily become trapped in those regions since the heuristic values of their states may need to be updated multiple times, which results in costly solutions. State-of-the-art real-time search algorithms, like LSS-LRTA∗ or LRTA∗(k), improve LRTA∗’s mechanism to update the heuristic, resulting in improved performance. Those algorithms, however, do not guide search towards avoiding depressed regions. This paper presents depression avoidance, a simple real-time search principle to guide search towards avoiding states that have been marked as part of a heuristic depression. We propose two ways in which depression avoidance can be implemented: mark-and-avoid and move-to-border. We implement these strategies on top of LSS-LRTA∗ and RTAA∗, producing 4 new real-time heuristic search algorithms: aLSS-LRTA∗, daLSS-LRTA∗, aRTAA∗, and daRTAA∗. When the objective is to find a single solution by running the real-time search algorithm once, we show that daLSS-LRTA∗ and daRTAA∗ outperform their predecessors sometimes by one order of magnitude. Of the four new algorithms, daRTAA∗ produces the best solutions given a fixed deadline on the average time allowed per planning episode. We prove all our algorithms have good theoretical properties: in finite search spaces, they find a solution if one exists, and converge to an optimal after a number of trials.
